qas.question: What age groups are usually enrolled in madaris?
How long does someone have to be enrolled in alim courses to earn a certificate or graduate?
In what ways are madaris similar to western colleges?

answers.text: people take evening classes and reside in dormitories

qas.question: Why do madaris extend enrollment to children of less fortunate circumstances?

answers.text: provide them with education and training

qas.question: What is the format for co-education for women in madaris?

answers.text: they study separately from the men

qas.question: What age groups are never enrolled in madaris?
How long does someone have to be enrolled in alim courses before they can drop out?

plausible_answers.text: evening classes and reside in dormitories

qas.question: In what ways are madaris similar to eastern colleges?

plausible_answers.text: provide them with education and training

qas.question: Why do madaris extend enrollment to rich children?
What is the format for co-education for adults in madaris?

context: People of <a0_0><b5_0>all ages<b5_0/><a0_0/> attend, and many often move on to becoming imams.[citation needed] The certificate of an ʻālim, for example, requires <a1_0><b6_0>approximately twelve years<b6_0/><a1_0/> of study.[citation needed] A good number of the ḥuffāẓ (plural of ḥāfiẓ) are the product of the madaris. The madaris also resemble colleges, where <a2_0>people take <b7_0>evening classes and reside in dormitories<b7_0/><a2_0/>. An important function of the madaris is to admit orphans and poor children in order to <a3_0><b8_0>provide them with education and training<b8_0/><a3_0/>. Madaris may enroll female students; however, <a4_0><b9_0>they study separately<b9_0/> from the men<a4_0/>.[citation needed]
